Award.AwardTitle: Strategic Problem-based Approach to Rouse Computer Science (SPARCS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SPARCS project will support 72 teachers of grades 7-9 to integrate computer science into their science and math instruction. Because the world is adopting computational tools quickly, students need to learn about how computational technology can be leveraged to make informed decisions. This project will help teachers integrate computational thinking and computer science principles into their teaching through these tools, by engaging students in projects that analyze data. The question of how to support secondary teachers to integrate computer science and real world related applications into their STEM instruction is on the cutting edge. This project will inform this issue.

Teachers will participate in a summer institute, online courses in computer science, monthly meetings during the school year, and mentorship with industry professionals. During the summer institute, teachers will work in small teams to create activities within a problem-based learning (PBL) framework, which they will implement in their classrooms during the school year. These activities will be informed by existing curricular resources, publicly available electronic data, and advice from industry experts and project staff. The efforts of these teachers will be documented through several forms of data, including elaborate teacher portfolios, observations, interviews, and student achievement results. These data will support refinement of the project from year 1 to year 3, and will be designed to communicate to other educators how to implement similar efforts in other schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SPARCS project adapts problem-based learning (PBL) to the teaching and learning of CS in middle schools. The key innovation is the strategic and systematic effort for creating personalized lesson plans and teaching portfolios incorporated into a Personalized Implementation Portfolio (PIP). This addresses two key challenges: (1) instilling student interest in CS and computing careers by using problems that have disciplinary, real-world, and personal authenticity, and (2) providing guidance for customizing the PBL to account for differences in teacher experiences, school districts, and course objectives.

Our approach was to introduce CS as a powerful problem solving process. In this respect, the lessons were structured according to well-known common activities of problem solving, e.g., definition, planning, implementation, and testing. Teachers personalized the lessons by developing a broad and ill-structured problem that is authentic to their discipline. The reflective approach of the Disciplinary Commons was used to successively refine the lesson outline into actual lesson modules. The Disciplinary Commons model was also used to identify data-driven improvements for improving how the lessons are taught.

Outcomes Related to Intellectual Merit

To demonstrate the generalizability of this approach, middle school teachers were recruited from urban, suburban and rural school districts.

The lessons were integrated into a diverse range of classrooms: Science (10), Technology (22), Engineering (2), Math (5), Language Arts (7), Music (2), Social Studies (3). This shows that the approach to create personalized implementation portfolios can successfully generate CS lessons in each of these diverse disciplines, in a variety of school contexts.

Teachers showed a statistically significant increase in several categories of the Teacher Perspectives Questionnaire. The TPQ measured the participants' perceptions about their CS knowledge, skills, and their ability to implement the Problem-Based Learning (PBL) methodology. The data (pre- and post-SPARCS) shows that the participants view themselves as having increased their knowledge of Computer Science, Computer Science Research, Mobile Applications, Programming, STEM Education, Cooperative Learning and Problem Based Learning through the SPARCS program.  After SPARCS, they say they are more confident about their CS skills and CS knowledge.

Teachers showed a statistically significant increase in several categories of the Computing Attitudes Survey. The CAS instrument compared teachers' answers regarding statements about CS to experts' answers. The data (pre- and post-SPARCS) on the CAS shows that the SPARCS teachers moved toward a more expert attitude about CS, especially in terms of approaching problem solving, increased personal interest, connecting CS to the real world, and developing a growth mindset.

Teachers were able to develop their personalized professional networks through SPARCS. The data on the Network Analysis survey shows that the participants began the program relatively isolated from CS partners and currently engage with an extensive set of CS partners in the Omaha Metro community.  

Teachers were mostly able to get their students to successfully create computational artifacts in the form of wireframes and storyboards, as well as implemented programs in Scratch, StarLogo Nova, App Inventor, and App Lab. 19 teachers had students produce code artifacts. Another 19 teachers had students produce digital or paper wireframes and storyboards. The rest of the teachers had students create other artifacts, e.g., websites, Powerpoint presentations, Excel worksheets, Google Map overlays, etc.

Four papers were presented at peer-reviewed conferences, introducing the SPARCS approach to conduct CS professional development by focusing on CS as a problem solving process (EIT 2017), identifying qualified master teachers (WiPSCE 2016), developing effective habits of reflective teaching (ICER 2017), and introducing a stepwise refinement approach for block programing (JCSC 2019).

Outcomes Related to Broader Impacts

66 teachers were recruited into 4 cohorts. This included 17 male and 49 female teachers. The racial demographic consists of 63 Caucasian, 1 African-American, 1 Hispanic, and 1 Asian. Of these, 53 completed the year-long training and 51 were able to teach lessons in class.

Teachers' self-reported estimates indicate 3,400 students were in these classes.

Another 73 teachers attended the 2019 dissemination workshops.

137 students participated in the SPARCS Student Academy held at the end of summer for teachers to test some of their lessons. These included 72 male and 65 female students. The racial demographic consists of 109 Caucasian, 12 African-American, 7 Hispanic, 5 Asian, and 4 multi-racial.

Selected (59) students showcased their projects at the Student Fair held as part of Nebraska Science Festival.

Several teachers became actively involved in their local Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) chapter, including serving as officers. 2 teachers presented their experiences at CSTA 2018.

11 teachers have started a MSCSEd degree program or CSEd teaching certificate.

Forged stronger connections to industry partners interested in supporting K-12 CS education, including, Mutual of Omaha, Union Pacific, Fiserv, and Blue Cross Blue Shield.

The success of SPARCS and other STEM efforts led to the establishment of STEM Teaching, Research, and Inquiry-Based Learning Center (STEM TRAILS) at UNO, an administrative unit supporting the further growth of STEM educational pathways. This Center was inaugurated in Fall 2019.
